questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with sudden onset weakness of the right arm and leg, along with drooping of the left eyelid and inability to move the left eye. MRI reveals an infarct in the midbrain. Which of the following best describes the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option B (Weber syndrome):

  • Weber syndrome occurs due to infarction of the midbrain affecting the cerebral peduncle and the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III).
  • This results in ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy (ptosis, dilated pupil, inability to move the eye in certain directions) and contralateral hemiparesis due to involvement of the corticospinal tract in the cerebral peduncle.
  • The characteristic combination of third nerve palsy and contralateral weakness is diagnostic for Weber syndrome.
  • The patient's symptoms of ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis match the clinical features of Weber syndrome.

Option A (Benedikt syndrome):

  • Benedikt syndrome is another midbrain stroke syndrome that also involves the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), causing ipsilateral third nerve palsy.
  • However, it differs from Weber syndrome by also involving the red nucleus, which leads to contralateral involuntary movements such as tremors, ataxia, or choreiform movements (due to involvement of the rubrospinal tract).
  • The patient's presentation lacks the characteristic involuntary movements seen in Benedikt syndrome and is more consistent with Weber syndrome's motor weakness and oculomotor findings.

Option C (Millard-Gubler syndrome):

  • Millard-Gubler syndrome results from a lesion in the pons affecting the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) on the ipsilateral side, along with the corticospinal tract. This leads to ipsilateral facial weakness, ipsilateral inability to abduct the eye, and contralateral hemiparesis.

Option D (Foville syndrome):

  • Foville syndrome is a pontine lesion affecting the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI), facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), and corticospinal tract. It presents with ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy, ipsilateral facial weakness, and contralateral hemiparesis.

Key Points:

  • Weber syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis due to a midbrain infarct.
  • Other brainstem syndromes such as Benedikt, Millard-Gubler, and Foville involve different cranial nerves and regions of the brainstem, leading to distinct clinical presentations.

Midbrain and Pons syndrome

Topic: Cerebrovascular stroke:Stroke syndrome

Difficulty Level: May know

PYQ: NEET 2020, INICET2021, 2022

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, page number. 3328, 3333

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty walking long distances, and calf muscle hypertrophy. He was able to walk independently until age 15 and remains ambulatory, though with some difficulty. Genetic testing shows a partially functional dystrophin protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B (Becker Muscular Dystrophy):

  • Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) is a milder dystrophinopathy caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, leading to the production of a partially functional dystrophin protein. Symptoms usually appear in adolescence or early adulthood, and patients remain ambulatory longer than in DMD, often into their 30s or 40s.
  • The patient's later onset of symptoms, slower progression, and presence of partially functional dystrophin make BMD the most likely diagnosis.

  • Calf hypertrophy

Option A (Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy):

  • Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is characterized by earlier onset (typically before age 5), rapid progression, and loss of ambulation by the early teenage years. It is caused by a lack of functional dystrophin.
  • This patient has a later onset and slower progression, which is more consistent with Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD).

Option C (Limb-Girdle Muscular Dystrophy):

  • Limb-Girdle Muscular Dystrophy (LGMD) refers to a group of muscular dystrophies that affect the shoulder and hip girdle muscles. It typically has a more variable onset and lacks the calf hypertrophy and specific genetic mutations seen in dystrophinopathies.
  • While LGMD causes muscle weakness, it is not associated with dystrophin mutations.

Option D (Emery-Dreifuss Muscular Dystrophy):

  • Emery-Dreifuss Muscular Dystrophy is a rare type of muscular dystrophy that often presents with early contractures of the elbows, neck, and ankles, and later with muscle weakness. It does not involve the dystrophin gene.
  • This condition does not match the patient's clinical presentation or genetic findings.

Key Points:

  • Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD): Early onset (before age 5), rapid progression, non-functional dystrophin.
  • Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD): Later onset, slower progression, partially functional dystrophin, patients remain ambulatory longer.

DMD vs BMD

Pattern of involvement in different muscular dystrophies:

Topic:Nerve and Muscle disorder:Muscular dystrophy

Difficulty Level:May know

PYQ:NEET 2020

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine,21st edition, page number.3521

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of head trauma presents with altered consciousness, dilated pupils, and decerebrate posturing. A CT scan of the head reveals a large subdural hematoma with midline shift. Which of the following is the most likely type of cerebral herniation?
questions.solution:
Option B (Uncal herniation):

  • Uncal herniation occurs when the medial part of the temporal lobe (uncus) is displaced over the tentorium, compressing the brainstem.
  • This often results in ipsilateral oculomotor nerve (CN III) compression (causing pupil dilation) and contralateral hemiparesis or decerebrate posturing due to brainstem compression.
  • The patient's dilated pupils and decerebrate posturing are classic signs of uncal herniation, which is commonly seen with mass effect from conditions like subdural hematoma.

Option A (transfalcine herniation):

  • Subfalcine herniation occurs when the cingulate gyrus is pushed under the falx cerebri.
  • This type of herniation can compress the anterior cerebral artery and cause leg weakness, but it does not typically cause pupillary dilation or decerebrate posturing.
  • The patient's presentation with dilated pupils and decerebrate posturing suggests brainstem involvement, which is more typical of uncal herniation.

Option C (Tonsillar herniation):

  • Tonsillar herniation occurs when the cerebellar tonsils are pushed through the foramen magnum, compressing the medulla. This causes life-threatening brainstem compression, leading to respiratory arrest and cardiovascular collapse.
  • Although serious, this form of herniation usually presents with signs of brainstem compression without the initial presentation of pupil dilation and decerebrate posturing seen in uncal herniation.

Option D (Central herniation):

  • Central herniation occurs when the diencephalon is displaced downward through the tentorial notch. This type of herniation typically leads to rapid decline in consciousness, bilateral small pupils, and decorticate or decerebrate posturing.

Key Points:

  • Uncal herniation: Causes ipsilateral pupil dilation (CN III compression) and contralateral motor deficits.
  • Transfalcine herniation: May cause leg weakness but does not affect the brainstem or cranial nerves.
  • Tonsillar herniation: Causes life-threatening brainstem compression, leading to cardiorespiratory arrest.
  • Central herniation: Involves downward displacement of brain structures, leading to bilateral symptoms.

Topic Name:Traumatic brain injury:Cerebral herniation

Difficulty Level:Must know

PYQ:FMGE 2021

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine,21st edition, page number:184

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with sudden-onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech that started 2 hours ago. He has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows no hemorrhage. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Option B: Administer intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)

tPA is the recommended treatment for eligible patients with acute ischemic stroke who present within 3-4.5 hours of symptom onset, and there is no evidence of hemorrhage on CT.

This patient qualifies for tPA because he is within the time window and has no contraindications (e.g., active bleeding, recent surgery).

Administering tPA can help dissolve the clot and restore blood flow to the affected area of the brain, improving outcomes.

Option A: Start aspirin and clopidogrel

While aspirin and clopidogrel are essential components of secondary prevention for ischemic stroke, they are not the first-line treatment in the acute phase if the patient is a candidate for tPA.

In this case, the patient presents within the <4.5 hour window for tPA, which is the preferred intervention.

Option C: Perform emergency carotid endarterectomy

Carotid endarterectomy is indicated for severe carotid stenosis but is not performed emergently in the setting of an acute ischemic stroke.

First, the patient should receive tPA to manage the acute stroke.

Endarterectomy may be considered later if carotid artery stenosis is identified as a cause of the stroke.

Option D: Start heparin for anticoagulation

Heparin is not routinely recommended in the acute phase of an ischemic stroke, as it has not been shown to improve outcomes and carries an increased risk of hemorrhage. The best option for eligible patients in the acute phase is tPA.

Mnemonic for Stroke Management:

"Time is Brain":

Act quickly to administer tPA within <4.5 hours of symptom onset for best outcomes.

Tags:

Topic: Neurology, Ischemic Stroke

Difficulty Level: May know

PYQ: INICET 2022

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page Number. 3338

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with chronic, severe burning pain in her right arm and leg following a stroke six months ago. She also has numbness and reduced sensation in the same areas. Her MRI reveals an infarct in the left thalamus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B (Dejerine-Roussy syndrome):

  • Dejerine-Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome, occurs due to a stroke affecting the thalamus, typically the posterior part.
  • It presents with chronic, severe burning pain and sensory loss in the contralateral side of the body, often months after the stroke. The syndrome is caused by damage to the thalamus, which is a key relay center for sensory information.
  • This patient's history of a thalamic infarct with subsequent development of contralateral burning pain and sensory loss is classic for Dejerine-Roussy syndrome.

Option A (Thalamic hemorrhage):

  • Thalamic hemorrhage is a type of intracerebral hemorrhage that can cause acute symptoms such as loss of sensation, weakness, altered consciousness, and sometimes severe headaches.
  • It does not typically result in chronic post-stroke pain. Hemorrhages usually present acutely, unlike the chronic pain syndrome described in this patient.

Option C (Lateral medullary syndrome):

  • Lateral medullary syndrome (also known as Wallenberg syndrome) is caused by an infarct in the lateral medulla, typically due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).
  • It presents with ipsilateral facial sensory loss, contralateral body sensory loss, ataxia, and sometimes Horner's syndrome.

Option D (Medial medullary syndrome):

  • Medial medullary syndrome is caused by an infarct in the medial medulla, often due to occlusion of the vertebral or anterior spinal arteries. It presents with contralateral hemiparesis, contralateral loss of proprioception, and ipsilateral tongue weakness (hypoglossal nerve involvement).

Key Points:

  • Dejerine-Roussy syndrome (thalamic pain syndrome) occurs after a stroke in the thalamus and presents with contralateral burning pain and sensory disturbances, typically months after the stroke.
  • Lateral medullary and medial medullary syndromes are brainstem infarcts with distinct presentations that differ from thalamic syndromes.

Topic: Cerebrovascular stroke:Stroke syndrome

Difficulty Level:May know

PYQ: NEET 2020, INICET2021,2022

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine,21st edition, page number.173,3328

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with weakness in his right leg and loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side of his body below the level of the umbilicus. He also has loss of proprioception in his right leg. Which of the following spinal cord syndromes is most likely?
questions.solution:
Option C (Brown-Sequard syndrome):

  • Brown-Sequard syndrome is caused by hemisection of the spinal cord.
  • It presents with ipsilateral weakness (due to corticospinal tract involvement), ipsilateral loss of proprioception and vibration (dorsal columns), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract) below the level of the lesion.
  • The patient's symptoms of ipsilateral motor and proprioceptive loss with contralateral loss of pain and temperature are classic for Brown-Sequard syndrome.

Option A (Central cord syndrome):

  • Central cord syndrome typically results from injury to the central part of the spinal cord, often seen in hyperextension injuries.
  • It affects the upper limbs more than the lower limbs and leads to a greater motor loss in the upper extremities.
  • Sensory loss is typically patchy, and there may be loss of pain and temperature sensation in a "cape-like" distribution over the shoulders.

Option B (Anterior cord syndrome):

  • Anterior cord syndrome is caused by damage to the anterior portion of the spinal cord, often due to ischemia.
  • It results in bilateral loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation below the level of the lesion.
  • Proprioception and vibration sense (dorsal columns) are usually spared because they are supplied by the posterior spinal arteries.

Option D (Posterior cord syndrome):

  • Posterior cord syndrome results from damage to the dorsal columns, leading to loss of proprioception, vibration sense, and fine touch below the level of the lesion. Motor function and pain/temperature sensation are typically preserved.
  • The patient's motor deficits and loss of pain/temperature sensation are not typical of posterior cord syndrome, which primarily affects proprioception.

Key Points:

  • Brown-Sequard syndrome is caused by a hemisection of the spinal cord and presents with:
    • Ipsilateral motor weakness and loss of proprioception/vibration.
    • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

  • Other spinal cord syndromes like central cord and anterior cord present with more generalized or different patterns of motor and sensory deficits.

Transverse section through the spinal cord,


Topic:Disorders of spinal cord:Brown sequard syndrome

Difficulty Level:Must know

PYQ: INICET 2022,NEET 2019

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, page number.167,172,3446

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with fever, headache, and neck stiffness since 20 days. CSF analysis shows elevated protein, low glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. CSF cryptococcal antigen negative.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Tuberculous meningitis: subacute presentation, lymphocytic predominance, elevated protein, and low glucose in the CSF make tuberculous meningitis the most likely diagnosis. These findings are classic for TBM.

Tuberculous Meningitis: This patient's presentation of fever, headache, and neck stiffness, along with CSF findings showing high protein, low glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis, is consistent with tuberculous meningitis (TBM). TBM typically presents subacutely and is associated with a history of tuberculosis or exposure to TB. The hallmark CSF findings in TB meningitis include low glucose (hypoglycorrhachia), elevated protein, and a predominance of lymphocytes.

Tuberculous meningitis is particularly common in immunocompromised patients or those from areas endemic to tuberculosis.

Option A:Bacterial meningitis typically presents with an acute onset and neutrophilic pleocytosis on CSF analysis. The glucose in bacterial meningitis is often very low, but the CSF generally shows neutrophils rather than lymphocytes, making bacterial meningitis less likely in this case.

Option B: Viral meningitis usually has a milder course than tuberculous or bacterial meningitis, with normal or slightly reduced glucose and lymphocytic pleocytosis. The patient's presentation and CSF profile (significantly low glucose and high protein) do not match the typical findings in viral meningitis.

Option D: Fungal meningitis, especially Cryptococcal meningitis, is more common in immunocompromised patients and presents similarly to TBM with low glucose and lymphocytic pleocytosis.CSF cryptococcal antigen is negative rules out fungal meningitis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Tuberculous meningitis presents with subacute onset of symptoms and characteristic CSF findings of high protein, low glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. It is commonly associated with a history of tuberculosis or exposure to TB.

Tags :

Topic : Tubercular meningitis

Difficulty Level: Must know

PYQ : FMGE 2021,2022/NEET 2022/

Ref.Harrison's principles of internal medicine,21st edition, page number.1113

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of bilateral vision loss and weakness in her legs. She has a history of recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and transverse myelitis. MRI shows longitudinally extensive lesions in the spinal cord, and serum testing reveals antibodies against aquaporin-4 (AQP4). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C (Neuromyelitis Optica):

  • Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO) is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the optic nerves and spinal cord, leading to recurrent episodes of optic neuritis and transverse myelitis.
  • The presence of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) antibodies is a hallmark of NMO, and MRI typically shows longitudinally extensive spinal cord lesions (involving more than three vertebral segments).
  • The patient's presentation of bilateral optic neuritis, transverse myelitis, and AQP4 antibodies confirms a diagnosis of NMO.

Imaging findings in neuromyelitis optica: longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis, optic neuritis, and brainstem involvement. A. Sagittal fluid attenuation inversion recovery (FLAIR) cervical-spine MRI showing an area of increased signal change on T2-weighted imaging spanning >3 vertebral segments in length.

Option A (Multiple Sclerosis):

  • Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that typically presents with optic neuritis, motor weakness, and sensory changes.
  • However, MS tends to involve shorter lesions in the spinal cord (less than three segments) and does not usually involve antibodies against aquaporin-4. MS is more likely to have brain involvement with multiple lesions seen on MRI.
  • The presence of long spinal cord lesions (more than three vertebral segments) and aquaporin-4 antibodies strongly suggests Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO), not MS.

Option B (Guillain-Barré Syndrome):

  • Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute, immune-mediated peripheral neuropathy that typically presents with ascending paralysis and areflexia.
  • It does not involve optic neuritis, spinal cord lesions, or antibodies against aquaporin-4.

Option D (Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis - ADEM):

  • ADEM is a rare inflammatory demyelinating disease that primarily affects children and young adults. It typically follows an infection or vaccination and presents with encephalopathy, seizures, and multifocal neurological deficits.
  • ADEM usually has a monophasic course, and long spinal cord lesions with AQP4 antibodies are not characteristic.

Key Points:

  • Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO) is characterized by:
    • Recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis.
    • Longitudinally extensive spinal cord lesions (more than three vertebral segments).
    • Presence of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) antibodies.
  • Multiple Sclerosis typically has shorter spinal cord lesions and does not involve AQP4 antibodies.
  • Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)

Topic: Disorders of CNS:Neuromyelitis optica

Difficulty Level:May know

PYQ:FMGE 2021

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, page number.3477

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with progressive weakness in his limbs, muscle wasting, and fasciculations. He also has slurred speech and difficulty swallowing. On examination, there is evidence of both upper and lower motor neuron signs, including hyperreflexia, spasticity, muscle atrophy, and fasciculations. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis):

  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disease that affects both upper and lower motor neurons. It typically presents with muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations, and spasticity.
  • Both upper motor neuron signs (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity) and lower motor neuron signs (e.g., muscle wasting, fasciculations) are characteristic of ALS.
  • Bulbar symptoms like slurred speech and difficulty swallowing may also develop.
  • The combination of upper and lower motor neuron signs, progressive muscle wasting, and bulbar symptoms strongly suggests ALS.

Option A (Multiple Sclerosis):

  • Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a central nervous system demyelinating disorder that primarily affects the brain and spinal cord. MS typically presents with sensory disturbances, optic neuritis, and episodes of weakness or ataxia that vary over time. MS is more commonly associated with upper motor neuron signs, and lower motor neuron involvement is not typical.
  • This patient's presentation with both upper and lower motor neuron signs and muscle wasting is more consistent with ALS, not MS.

Option B (Myasthenia Gravis):

  • Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction, leading to fluctuating muscle weakness, especially of the eyes, face, and throat, but without muscle wasting or fasciculations.
  • MG typically involves normal reflexes and does not show upper motor neuron signs.
  • This patient has progressive weakness with upper and lower motor neuron signs, which is characteristic of ALS, not MG.

Option D (Guillain-Barré Syndrome):

  • Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune polyneuropathy that causes rapidly progressing ascending weakness. GBS predominantly affects the peripheral nervous system, leading to lower motor neuron signs such as weakness, areflexia, and flaccidity, but it does not cause fasciculations, muscle atrophy, or upper motor neuron signs.

Key Points:

  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is a motor neuron disease that affects both upper and lower motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations, and hyperreflexia.
  • Upper motor neuron signs include spasticity and hyperreflexia, while lower motor neuron signs include fasciculations, muscle atrophy, and weakness.

Topic :Disorders of CNS:Motor neuron disease

Difficulty Level:May know

PYQ:NEET SS 2020 / INICET 2021

Ref.Harrison'S principles of internal medicine,21st edition, page number.3477

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a head injury from a fall. He had a brief loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval, but now complains of severe headache, confusion, and drowsiness. A CT scan of the head shows a biconvex, hyperdense collection of blood between the skull and the dura. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B (Epidural Hematoma):

  • Epidural Hematomas (EDH) typically result from trauma causing rupture of the middle meningeal artery. It presents with a lucid interval followed by rapid neurological deterioration. On CT, it appears as a biconvex, lens-shaped collection of blood between the skull and the dura.
  • The patient's history of head trauma, lucid interval, and the characteristic biconvex shape on CT are classic findings of an epidural hematoma.

Option A (Subdural Hematoma):

  • Subdural hematomas result from the rupture of bridging veins, leading to a crescent-shaped collection of blood between the dura and the brain. It typically presents with a gradual decline in consciousness after a head injury and does not usually involve a lucid interval.
  • Incorrect: The patient's lucid interval and biconvex shape on CT suggest an epidural hematoma, not a subdural hematoma.

Option C (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage):

  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage is typically caused by the rupture of an aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation, leading to blood in the subarachnoid space. It presents with a sudden, severe headache ("thunderclap headache"), nausea, and vomiting, but does not typically follow a lucid interval or show biconvex blood collections on CT.

Option D (Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage):

  • Intraparenchymal hemorrhage involves bleeding within the brain tissue itself, often due to hypertension, trauma, or coagulopathy. It presents with sudden neurological deficits and is not typically associated with a lucid interval or biconvex blood collections on CT.
  • The CT findings and history of a lucid interval point to EDH rather than intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

Key Points:

  • Epidural Hematoma (EDH) is characterized by:
    • Lucid interval after head trauma.
    • Rapid deterioration due to middle meningeal artery rupture.
    • Biconvex, lens-shaped collection of blood on CT scan.
    • Prompt surgical intervention is often necessary to prevent life-threatening complications.

Topic:Concussion and traumatic brain injury:EDH

Difficulty Level:Must know

PYQ:FMGE 2020,2021

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, page number. 3477

choices.text: Myoclonic Epilepsy with Ragged Red Fibers (MERRF)
Mitochondrial Myopathy, Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like Episodes (MELAS)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with bilateral ptosis, progressive external ophthalmoplegia, and hearing loss. He has also experienced syncopal episodes and is noted to have pigmentary retinopathy on examination. A muscle biopsy shows ragged red fibers, and his cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D (Kearns-Sayre Syndrome - KSS):

KSS is characterized by a triad of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO), pigmentary retinopathy, and onset before the age of 20. The patient also has cardiac conduction abnormalities (e.g., heart block), which is a hallmark of KSS. Muscle biopsy showing ragged red fibers and elevated CSF protein further supports this diagnosis.

Option A (Myoclonic Epilepsy with Ragged Red Fibers - MERRF):

MERRF is characterized by myoclonic epilepsy, cerebellar ataxia, and muscle weakness. It is associated with the A8344G mutation in mitochondrial DNA. Although ragged red fibers are seen in both MERRF and KSS, the absence of seizures and the presence of external ophthalmoplegia, heart block, and pigmentary retinopathy point more towards KSS.

Option B (Mitochondrial Myopathy, Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like Episodes - MELAS):

MELAS is characterized by stroke-like episodes, seizures, and progressive muscle weakness. The onset is often before age 20, but the hallmark symptoms of stroke-like episodes and seizures are not present in this case. KSS is more likely due to the cardiac involvement and external ophthalmoplegia.

Option C (Progressive External Ophthalmoplegia - PEO):

PEO involves progressive external ophthalmoplegia and muscle weakness. However, the absence of additional systemic involvement (such as cardiac conduction defects) differentiates it from KSS, which has more severe and systemic features, including heart block.

Key Points:

  • Kearns-Sayre Syndrome (KSS) is characterized by:
    • Progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO), pigmentary retinopathy, and cardiac conduction defects.
    • Often presents with additional systemic features, including hearing loss, short stature, and endocrinopathies.
    • Muscle biopsy typically shows ragged red fibers and elevated CSF protein.

Topic :Nerve and muscle disease:Mitochondrial myopathies

Difficulty Level:Good to know

PYQ:NEET 2020

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, page number.3529

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech that lasted for about 30 minutes before resolving completely. He is a smoker and had a similar episode two weeks ago. On examination, his blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg. Based on the ABCD² score, which factor contributes the highest number of points in assessing his risk for stroke following this TIA?
questions.solution:
Option C (Duration of TIA symptoms):
Duration of TIA symptoms is a key factor in the ABCD² score. If the symptoms last between 10 and 59 minutes, it adds 1 point. If they last for 60 minutes or more, it adds 2 points. In this case, the patient's symptoms lasted for 30 minutes, contributing 1 point for duration, which is a significant contributor.

Option A (Age ≥60 years):
In the ABCD² score, age ≥60 years adds 1 point. The patient's age of 70 years contributes to his score, but it is not the highest single contributor.

Option B (Blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg):
A blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg adds 1 point in the ABCD² scoring system. The patient's blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg would contribute 1 point, but again, this is not the highest contributor.

Option D (History of diabetes):
History of diabetes contributes 1 point in the ABCD² score. The patient's history of diabetes adds to the overall score, but it is not the highest single contributor.

Key Points about the ABCD² Score:

Topic:Cerebrovascular stroke:TIA

Difficulty Level:Must know

PYQ: INICET 2020

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, page number.3344

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a head injury. He opens his eyes only to painful stimuli, produces incomprehensible sounds, and shows abnormal flexion in response to pain. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
1. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) assesses a patient's level of consciousness based on three components: Eye Opening (E), Verbal Response (V), and Motor Response (M). The scale is scored as follows:

Eye Opening to Painful Stimuli (E2) = 2 points.

Incomprehensible sounds (V2) = 2 points.

Abnormal flexion to pain (M3) = 3 points.

GCS Calculation :

Total GCS = 2 + 2 + 3 = 7

Key Points:

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale is used to assess the severity of brain injury.
    • Mild injury: GCS 13-15
    • Moderate injury: GCS 9-12
    • Severe injury: GCS ≤ 8
  • In this case, the patient's score of 7 suggests severe brain injury.

Topic :Glass glow coma score

Difficulty Level:Must know

PYQ:NEET 2023,FMGE 2021,2022

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st edition, page number. 2218

questions.text: Which of the following environmental factors has been most strongly associated with an increased risk of developing Multiple Sclerosis (MS)?
questions.solution:
Option B (Exposure to Epstein-Barr virus - EBV):
Exposure to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), especially later in childhood or adolescence, has been consistently associated with an increased risk of developing MS. EBV causes infectious mononucleosis, and individuals who develop this infection late in life are at a higher risk for MS.

Option A (High dietary fat intake):
While diet can influence overall health, there is no clear link between high dietary fat intake and the development of MS. Other factors such as vitamin D levels and infections are more critical in MS risk.

Option C (Chronic alcohol use):
While alcohol use is associated with various health conditions, it is not recognized as a significant risk factor for MS. Smoking, on the other hand, has been shown to increase the risk.

Option D (Excessive sun exposure):
On the contrary, sun exposure helps in the synthesis of vitamin D, which has protective effects against MS. Low vitamin D levels are linked with a higher risk of MS, especially in regions with less sunlight.

Risk factors for Multiple Sclerosis

Key Points:

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, particularly infectious mononucleosis, is a significant environmental factor linked to MS.
  • Other risk factors include vitamin D deficiency, cigarette smoking, and genetic predisposition.
  • MS prevalence has increased over the past decades, particularly in women, likely due to environmental factors like lifestyle changes and sun exposure reduction.

Topic:Demyelinating disorders of CNS:Multiple sclerosis

Difficulty Level:May know

PYQ:NEET 2020/ INICET 2021

Reference.Harrison's principles of internal medicine,21st edition, page number.3464

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is the most common cause of viral (aseptic) meningitis?
questions.solution:
B) Enteroviruses: Enteroviruses (such as coxsackie viruses and echo viruses) are the most common cause of viral meningitis, especially in children. They account for the majority of cases, particularly during summer and fall.

A) Herpes simplex virus (HSV): HSV, particularly HSV-2, can cause viral meningitis, but it is more commonly associated with encephalitis. It is not the most common cause of viral meningitis.

C) Varicella-zoster virus (VZV): VZV can cause viral meningitis, especially in immunocompromised individuals or following shingles (herpes zoster), but it is less common than enteroviruses.

D) Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV): HIV can cause viral meningitis, especially in the acute stage of infection (acute retroviral syndrome), but it is not the most common cause.

Key to remember:

Topic:Neuroinfection:Viral meningitis

Difficulty:May know

PYQ:NEET 2023,FMGE2023

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine,21st edition, page number.1106
